content: Consulting managers can use this page for any purpose they wish, like adding meeting notes, business discussions or any template (s)he likes.

Creating customer-specific know-how ensures all critical information and unique aspects of the project requirements.

## Client Summary

noteCompany Name: XYZ CropSector:Technology

Brands:~150

Revenue: $150 billion (FY 2024)

Product Count: ~ 98K SKUs

Key Products:

1. Smartphones
2. Laptops
3. Cloud Services

Headquarters:Silicon Valley, California, USA

Global Reach:Operations in over 5 countries, with ~ 850 stores

Project Scope:

- Regions In Scope: PL(Poland), CZ(Czechia), SK(Slovakia), RO(Romania), HU(Hungary)
- Store Scope: Brand Type: Retail,
- Out-of-Store Scope: E-commerce

Solutions:Transfer, Replenishment

## Client Meeting Details

Fill in the client meeting details in the table below

|  | Schedule | Agenda |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Q&A Session | - | Client gives updates on created runs and ask questions if they have. |
| KPI Review | - | TRN performance KPI follow ups and discussions. |
| Business Meetings | e.g Twice a week, on Tuesday's and Thursday's | Task list and discussion topics. |
| Steerco | e.g Once a month. | KPI shares and updates. |
| Data Collection | e.g Once a week. | Implementation and hypercare topics are discussed. Can be canceled after handover to CX support. |
| PM | e.g Once a week. | Client project leads and Invent managers attends the meeting, and discuss ongoing topics / expectations. |

Understanding the data transfer process during a handover is crucial because this ensures that the transition is smooth and secure, and maintains the integrity and continuity of operations. Here is a [1.1 Data Transfer Process] from an existing client.

## Flow

- The customer sends daily data to invent-xxx-input/daily_data/ in Microsoft Azure Storage every night at 2.30 AM.
- …

## Daily File Instructions

Fill in the table below for files transferred using the daily data process.

| File Name | Datastore Folder | Critical |
| --- | --- | --- |
| eg. transactional_sales.csv | operation/transactional_salesoperation/sales | Yes |
| eg. supplier.csv | master-data/suppliers | No |
|  |  |  |

> Info: The critical column contains information on whether we can continue from the previous day if the customer does not send the file.

## Manual File Instructions

Fill in the table below for files not transferred using the daily data process.

l File Instructions

| File Name | Datastore Folder | Critical | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| eg. supersede_item_family | invent-ebebek2-filemanager-ui/supersede_relations/ | No | We receive this file with UPLOAD MANAGEMENT via interfaces. |
|  |  |  |  |

## Special Cases

noteClient Specific Terminologies:

- e.g. You can enter instances like Style Color = Option, Site = Store, etc.

Special Days:

- e.g. Christmas period should be ignored from ignore table to avoid forecast fluctuation.

Special Rules:

- e.g. Pairs are eliminated from run scopes if not in the initial allocation scope. (Except stock consolidation runs)

Client Specific Terminologies:

- e.g. You can enter instances like Style Color = Option, Site = Store, etc.

Special Days:

- e.g. Christmas period should be ignored from ignore table to avoid forecast fluctuation.

Special Rules:

- e.g. Pairs are eliminated from run scopes if not in the initial allocation scope. (Except stock consolidation runs)

## Pager Duty

> Info: For PagerDuty setup, please contact the CX-IT Rocks team.

PagerDuty is an incident management and notification tool that integrates well with Airflow to alert teams in case of task or job failures. Teams can use PagerDuty to receive alerts when a task or Dag fails, helping ensure a timely response to critical issues.

## SLA and Timeout

SLA and Timeout are mechanisms to manage task and workflow performance, ensuring that tasks or DAGs complete within expected timeframes. They help identify tasks that are running longer than expected, allowing for invention, alerting, or fail-safe measures.

asks that are running longer than expected, allowing for invention, alerting, or fail-safe measures.

Welcome to your new space!
Spaces help your team structure, organize, and share work, so every team member has visibility into institutional knowledge and access to the information they need to do their best work.

"""
This script creates necessary tables to onboard a customer
"""
import os
from typing import NoReturn

from warp.core.pokedex import Pokedex
from warp.spark import get_spark_session
from warp.spark.pokedex import parse_schema_json

def generate_empty_df(
    customer: str,
    environment: str,
    cloud_provider: str,
    table_names: list
) -> NoReturn:
    """
    Given a customer, environment, cloud provider and table names creates empty
    spark data frames in the datastore to bootstrap shield dags

    Usage::
        generate_empty_df(
        "customer_name", "prod", "azure",
        [
            "product", "store", "warehouse",
            "supplier", "season", "uda", "run_rocket"
        ]
        )

:param customer: customer name
    :type customer: str
    :param environment: environment name
    :type environment: str
    :param cloud_provider: cloud provider name
    :type cloud_provider: str
    :param table_names: list of table names to create
    :type table_names: list
    """
    spark = get_spark_session()
    client = Pokedex(
        customer=customer, environment=environment,
        cloud_provider=cloud_provider
    )
    for table_name in table_names:
        response = client.get_metadata(name=table_name)
        metadata = response["data"][0]["metadata"]
        schema = parse_schema_json(schema=metadata["schema"])
        output_path_keys = metadata["path"]
        output_path = os.path.join(
            output_path_keys["file_schema"],
            output_path_keys["bucket"], output_path_keys["key"]
        )
        df = spark.createDataFrame([], schema=schema)
        print(output_path)
        df.write.format("delta").save(output_path, mode="overwrite")

ema)
        print(output_path)
        df.write.format("delta").save(output_path, mode="overwrite")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    customer_name = "..."
    generate_empty_df(
         customer_name, "prod", "azure",
        [
            "product", "store", "warehouse",
            "supplier", "season", "uda", "run_rocket"
        ]
    )

# Iceland Implementation Requirements

## Discovery Workshop Summary

Document Version: 1.0 | January 2026

---

# 1. Executive Summary

This document consolidates findings from five discovery workshops conducted with Iceland (frozen food retailer) between November 19 and December 8, 2025. It serves as the primary input for the implementation team to understand Iceland's current operations, pain points, and system requirements for the supply chain and forecasting solution.

Key areas covered include store replenishment, DC operations, forecasting methodology, volume smoothing, supplier management, and long lead time item handling.

---

# 2. Store Replenishment & Ordering

## 2.1 Order Processing

and long lead time item handling.

---

# 2. Store Replenishment & Ordering

## 2.1 Order Processing

- Orders are precalculated with fixed delivery and order dates
- Delays in order acceptance cause immediate availability issues at stores
- System does not provide flexibility on delivery timing once orders are suggested
- Balance notifications are triggered when stock reaches certain thresholds
- Maximum constraints exist for pallets and trucks

## 2.2 Min/Max Brackets

Two sets of brackets are maintained in the current system:

- Store min/max: Used for smoothing (e.g., min 40, max 600 cases to a store)
- DC inbound brackets: Supplier-side constraints
- DC outbound brackets do not exist separately; they use store inbound values

## 2.3 Slow Movers

ts
- DC outbound brackets do not exist separately; they use store inbound values

## 2.3 Slow Movers

- Slow movers are ordered only on Mondays
- Pet food big packs are an example where stores may only sell once a week
- Lost sales for slow movers is an area requiring attention
- Decision on slow mover handling must be made during design phase

## 2.4 Manual and Urgent Orders

- Urgent orders go directly to depot (in-day orders can be accommodated)
- Custom orders supported (e.g., charity orders for 1000+ boxes)
- Can be mapped to custom order generation screen

## 2.5 New Store Setup

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| New stores per year | Approximately 20 |
| Setup time | Typically 8 weeks minimum |
| Reference stores | Copy store approach used for initial ranging |

me | Typically 8 weeks minimum |
| Reference stores | Copy store approach used for initial ranging |

- Manual stores start with grocery: one case of everything for shop facing
- Short life products added at the end of setup
- Store closures data can be used; ranging may start earlier
- Refit stores may have different closure days (Friday vs Sunday)

---

# 3. Distribution Center Operations

## 3.1 Pick-to-Zero Process

- All chilled and short-life items use pick-to-zero process
- Not all chilled is pick-to-zero, but all pick-to-zero items are chilled
- Chilled pick typically starts at midday
- Receipt info available for pick-to-zero items

## 3.2 Depot Timing and Processing

### Livingston Depot (Exception Case)

- Does not receive ASN confirmations
- Orders calculated based on latest store stock estimation at 2-3 AM
- Supply shortages or overages not known in advance

### General Processing

ock estimation at 2-3 AM
- Supply shortages or overages not known in advance

### General Processing

- Warrington depot: 11am indicates receiving finished
- Pick-to-zero takes 20 minutes on Iceland side
- Additional 20 minutes in WHS management system
- GXO handles the actual picking
- 5-10 minutes allocated for reallocation

## 3.3 Cross-Dock Operations

- Multiple orders consolidated for a single depot
- Some suppliers can deliver to some depots but not all stores
- Rule-based for efficiency and cost optimization
- System checks combined forecast for depot A and B, then creates orders
- Stock shipped between depots for efficiency (no cost data available for optimization)

## 3.4 Inter-Depot Transfers (IDT)

- Currently mostly manual process
- Planners write down overstock on sheets and calculate manually
- Very ad-hoc with no specific timeline
- Sometimes driven by supplier agreements to ship only to specific depots
- Case pick supported in IDT
- Pallet IDs provided for tracking

ents to ship only to specific depots
- Case pick supported in IDT
- Pallet IDs provided for tracking

## 3.5 Capacity Management

- Exceeding daily inbound capacity is common
- Warehouse storage cap remains fixed (e.g., 10 pallets)
- Daily inbound capacity can increase
- Planning team looks ahead to manage volume
- Target: ~1000 pallets/day picking capacity
- Utilization is very low Monday morning; drain over weekend (may not be optimal)
- 10 AM daily checkpoint

---

# 4. Forecasting & Demand Planning

## 4.1 Current Forecasting Approach

- Weather, holiday, and seasonal forecasting discussed but not in deep detail
- Pattern changes believed to exist but orders are summed up for ordering purposes
- Wholesale is not forecasted - pure customer demand (come and buy only)
- Recent forecast changes may not be captured in overnight runs
- Range stores less reliable for transmission accuracy

## 4.2 Measurement & KPIs

in overnight runs
- Range stores less reliable for transmission accuracy

## 4.2 Measurement & KPIs

- No formal KPI for volume smoothing performance currently
- Only measure cases removed/added to understand adjustment volume
- Planners investigate products with most unavailable stock vs ordered

## 4.3 Events and Special Situations

- Store issues: Need UI explanation for system integration
- Events like London Marathon: Need UI explanation
- Feature space: Promo at shelf beginning or standalone feature offer
- Ramadan example: Need method to identify stores affected
- Bad events: Examples needed from Dan
- Easter: Demand shifting example
- Short-life forecasting: They don't want to react to it (Steve Jones)

## 4.4 Intermittent Demand

- Channel item chilled is best example for franchise
- Phantom stock and phantom data considerations
- Stock adjustment and correction at product-store level
- Weekly rebalancing by system (Steve Jones)

---

# 5. Volume Smoothing

tion at product-store level
- Weekly rebalancing by system (Steve Jones)

---

# 5. Volume Smoothing

## 5.1 Current Process

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| Duration | 1-2 hours in the morning |
| Responsible Team | Steve Jones' team |
| Frequency | Daily |

- Data available for users to review
- Changes happen mostly during the week
- Forecast is agreed with depot beforehand for visibility
- Automation is highly desired

## 5.2 Requirements

- For chilled: Ability to shape forecast and push/pull volume
- No automation currently on smoothing side for chilled
- ~120k volume upcoming for few weeks
- Reserve some volume due to waste concerns
- Need to see latest inventory at store level
- Long lead times need to be processed first in the morning
- Waste visibility needed in the morning

## 5.3 Future Pull Forward

They currently run daily smoothing, so future pull forward would be a massive update to the current way of working. This needs to be deep-dived during implementation.

e a massive update to the current way of working. This needs to be deep-dived during implementation.

# 6. Supplier Management

## 6.1 Supplier Relationships

- Vast majority of supplier relationships are fixed
- Don't switch supplier to supplier typically
- Fresh products sometimes can switch
- Predefined percentages across suppliers when splitting

## 6.2 Supplier Splits

- Very few genuinely split orders
- Some instances of PO duplication (holy relation)
- Linked into consolidation process
- One supplier can only do half depot to certain depots
- Example: Brickwick, Coca Cola, Heinz - want to order in a truck
- Purchase order groups: Output is 3 orders under different sub-vendors
- Frozen has lots of consolidation

## 6.3 Third-Party Organizations

Several third-party organizations are involved in the supply chain:

# 6.3 Third-Party Organizations

Several third-party organizations are involved in the supply chain:

- West Bridge: Works with individual suppliers for overseas items
- iTechs Limited: Another organization supplying Iceland
- Wholesale relationships pass back to these companies
- SSO access available for these parties

## 6.4 ASN and Confirmations

- Some suppliers don't provide ASN
- Confirmed quantity received on certain day of time
- Automatic confirmation sounds appealing
- Bread and milk orders have earlier deadlines
- Fixed order volume: store-product-qty should change (e.g., 100 to 98)
- ASN confirms what they can physically order for the batch

# 7. Long Lead Time Items (Overseas)

## 7.1 Current Challenges

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| Typical Lead Time | 12 weeks for overseas items |

Challenges

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| Typical Lead Time | 12 weeks for overseas items |

- Items are regular with quite consistent demand (fast lines)
- Challenge is managing where orders are going (currently manual)
- Want to track depot allocation in more robust way
- Trying to ensure demand is covered
- Problem to solve: Certainty in planning

## 7.2 Container Handling

Example scenario: Order from Thailand arrives at UK port

- Currently don't want to commit to specific depot (e.g., Enfield) at arrival
- Done manually based on spreadsheets
- No system tracking currently
- Containers may arrive 4 weeks earlier than planned
- Week advance typically 10 days ahead

## 7.3 Required Functionality - PO Splits

The system should support:

- Creating bulk orders not initially related to specific depots
- Sending notifications when containers arrive
- Running optimization for PO splits
- Selecting POs and available warehouses

when containers arrive
- Running optimization for PO splits
- Selecting POs and available warehouses

This is exactly what Iceland needs - the PO split functionality.

## 7.4 New Lines Handling

- No system setup currently for new overseas lines
- Don't split containers and don't want to split
- If split, creates unique handling requirements
- External suppliers involved (West Bridge relationship)

# 8. Bread & Fresh Products

## 8.1 Bread Orders

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| SKU Count | ~300 bread items |
| Major Suppliers | One big one + 3 in total |
| Order Deadline | 10:30 AM for suppliers |

- 24h and 48h advance orders sent to supplier
- This is an ERP process - order merging on schedule
- Monday orders for Wednesday, Tuesday orders for Wednesday, etc.

## 8.2 Positive Receiving Process

- Monday orders for Wednesday, Tuesday orders for Wednesday, etc.

## 8.2 Positive Receiving Process

- Take two orders and combine them (24h and 48h)
- Earlier deadlines than other products
- Monday morning batch of store orders calculated
- If happy, approve and aggregate to product-depot level
- Then sent to supplier
- Press button to indicate stock received
- Rebalance based on actual stock
- Don't reference open PO; chilled pick starts midday

## 8.3 Waste Management

- Process exists for waste and price reductions
- Store controlled
- Iceland waste cost needs to be quantified

# 9. Product Hierarchy & Relationships

## 9.1 Parent-Child Relationships

- Each product has a parent code
- Each parent code can map to single or multiple children
- Parent-to-parent = supersede (automatic switch)
- Shipper is a separate ordering code

## 9.2 Supersede vs Reference

= supersede (automatic switch)
- Shipper is a separate ordering code

## 9.2 Supersede vs Reference

- Parent A running down: Don't over-order parent A but actually send parent B
- If no stock in parent A but B is blocked: System forces to B
- Extra free items have different codes - use inventory reference, not supersede
- Forces and lows in item family: Can set parent as priority 1 (forces)
- Confident about parent relations in master data

## 9.3 Variants and Casepacks

- Store-level casepack supported
- Example: Sugar 15 items in case, 4 pallet variant; small stores get lower qty
- Normal variant: Heinz baked beans 6 for price of 4, or 10-pack
- Product code is only referenceable for a depot; store says parent
- Multiple casepacks maintained for tracking
- On order for top code; on hand arrives in bottom code
- Reports may need to be at parent level
- Depot-level family relation solution may be needed

- Depot-level family relation solution may be needed

# 10. Promotions

## 10.1 Promotion Types

- 10% student discount exists
- Feature space: Promo at beginning of shelf or standalone non-promo feature
- Online promos not tracked well; may change multiple times per day
- Axiom system holds all promotions

## 10.2 Current Limitations

- Promo doesn't specify which locations
- Planned promotions can be requested; actuals can be provided
- Overseas items don't have promotions (which is good for forecasting)

## 10.3 Holdout and Rundown

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |
| Example | 100 units stock, holdout for 4 weeks |

- Rundown logic for critical stock needs clarification (Cassandra not present)
- Promotions with overstock: Can provide alerts for excess presentation stock
- Some stores won't sell in 14 days of feature; rundown should be configurable

# 11. System Integration & Technical Details

## 11.1 Blue Yonder Integration

Blue Yonder Merchandising (similar to Boots setup):

- Floor plan and store ranging
- Shelf caps: Frozen = 40, Grocery = 25
- Can be configured by store, product, and depot

## 11.2 Online Sales

- Online sales attached to online data
- Inventory deducted from same pool
- Dotcom orders are inside lead time (e.g., today ordered, 2-5pm delivery window)
- Similar to many other clients

## 11.3 Data Availability

| Parameter | Value |
| --- | --- |

are aggregated at product level
